rationale: No intensifier or comparative adjective modifies a risk-adjective.
statement_text: "I've been a student of this virus [H5N1]. And I surely have been amazed at how it's [it] changed over the course of the last 20-some years, but at the same time, you know, I'm looking for evidence that it [it] is likely to become a virus infecting humans and then transmitted by humans to other humans. "And I surely have been amazed at how it's changed over the course of the last 20-some years, but at the same time, you know, I'm looking for evidence that it is likely to become a virus infecting humans and then transmitted by humans to other humans. And we just haven't seen that [evidence of human-to-human transmission] yet," he [Dr. Michael Osterholm] added.

rationale: 'amazed' is subjective reaction; 'likely to become' is about potential future risk.
